coredata.dc:title: Simulated solar light driven photothermal catalytic purification of toluene over iron oxide supported single atom Pt catalyst
coredata.dc:creator: Wang, Zhiwei

coredata.dc:description: In this work, Fe2O3 supported single atom Pt (x Pt1/Fe2O3, x = 0.25 and 0.5 wt%) catalysts (SACs) are synthesized via a novel and simple impregnation-pyrolysis method. HAADF-STEM images show that Pt is atomically dispersed on the surface of Fe2O3. All samples exhibit good light-thermal conversion efficiency, which can increase the surface temperature of catalysts to 210 °C. The 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 exhibits the best photothermal catalytic performance (the toluene conversion and CO2 yield are 95 % and 87 %, respectively) for toluene oxidation under the irradiation of simulated sunlight with light intensity of 720 mW/cm2, which is attributed to its good light-thermal conversion efficiency and low temperature reducibility. The Vis-IR light plays a critical role in the photothermal catalytic oxidation of toluene in the whole solar spectrum. Furthermore, the possible photothermal catalytic reaction pathway of toluene oxidation is proposed based on the TD-GC/MS and in-situ DRIFTS experiments.

Light-driven photothermal catalysis
Toluene oxidation
Catalytic oxidation mechanism
Volatile organic compounds

xocs:item-toc-entry.xocs:item-toc-section-title: Crystal phase composition, morphology, and textural property
Photothermal catalytic mechanism for toluene oxidation over Pt1/Fe2O3
Photothermal catalytic stability and H2O, CO2, and SO2 tolerance

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (A) HAADF-STEM and (B) EDS elemental mapping images of 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3; (C) in-situ DRIFTS spectra of CO adsorption over 0.25 Pt1/Fe2O3 and 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3.

(A) Toluene conversion and CO2 yield over Fe2O3, 0.25 Pt1/Fe2O3, and 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 under the irradiation of simulated sunlight with 720 mW/cm2 light intensity; (B) Toluene conversion and CO2 yield over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 under the irradiation of simulated sunlight with different light intensities.

(A) Toluene conversion and CO2 yield over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 under the irradiation of simulated sunlight, UV–vis, and IR light with the same light intensity of 720 mW/cm2 or at the same temperature of 210 °C; (B) Toluene conversion and CO2 yield over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 under the irradiation of simulated sunlight, Vis-IR, UV–vis, IR, and Vis light.
(A) H2-TPR profiles and (B) O 1s XPS spectra of (a) Fe2O3, (b) 0.25 Pt1/Fe2O3, and (c) 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3.
(A) Possible reaction intermediate products detected by TD-GC/MS and (B) in-situ DRIFTS spectra for toluene oxidation over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3.
(A) Catalytic stability, and effect of (B) H2O, (C) CO2, and (D) SO2 on the catalytic activity over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 for toluene oxidation under irradiation of simulated sunlight.
Possible photothermal catalytic mechanism for toluene oxidation over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 under irradiation of simulated sunlight.

head.ce:title: Simulated solar light driven photothermal catalytic purification of toluene over iron oxide supported single atom Pt catalyst

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: In this work, Fe2O3 supported single atom Pt (x Pt1/Fe2O3, x = 0.25 and 0.5 wt%) catalysts (SACs) are synthesized via a novel and simple impregnation-pyrolysis method. HAADF-STEM images show that Pt is atomically dispersed on the surface of Fe2O3. All samples exhibit good light-thermal conversion efficiency, which can increase the surface temperature of catalysts to 210 °C. The 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 exhibits the best photothermal catalytic performance (the toluene conversion and CO2 yield are 95 % and 87 %, respectively) for toluene oxidation under the irradiation of simulated sunlight with light intensity of 720 mW/cm2, which is attributed to its good light-thermal conversion efficiency and low temperature reducibility. The Vis-IR light plays a critical role in the photothermal catalytic oxidation of toluene in the whole solar spectrum. Furthermore, the possible photothermal catalytic reaction pathway of toluene oxidation is proposed based on the TD-GC/MS and in-situ DRIFTS experiments.

ce:section.ce:para: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emitted from various industrial processes are considered as main air pollutants, which can seriously destroy the ecological environment and endanger the health of human body [1–4]. So far, various techniques such as absorption [5], biodegradation [6], plasma decomposition [7], photocatalytic oxidation [8], and catalytic oxidation [9–13] have been developed for the abatement of VOCs. With some outstanding advantages such as the high removal efficiency, low operation temperature, and little secondary pollution, catalytic oxidation is generally regarded as the most efficient technique for the abatement of low concentration VOCs [14]. However, the major challenge for catalytic oxidation is the high energy consumption [15]. To solve this problem, researchers begin to focus on the solar light-driven thermal catalytic oxidation of VOCs for taking full advantage of the inexhaustible solar energy [16,17]. Compared with the conventional photocatalytic oxidation, light-driven thermal catalysis can make full use of ultraviolet, visible and infrared light in the solar spectrum, and convert light into heat. Therefore, it is highly demanded to develop photothermal catalysts with high utilization of solar energy and excellent catalytic activity.

In recent years, metal oxide [18,19] and supported noble metal catalysts are widely used in the photothermal catalytic oxidation of VOCs [20–24]. Compared with metal oxide catalysts, supported noble metal catalysts exhibit higher catalytic activity (especially supported Pt catalyst) [21,21,22,23,24]. However, the supported noble metals usually exist in the form of nanoparticles. Only the surface atoms of the supported noble metal participate in the reaction of heterogeneous catalysis, which causes enormous waste of noble metal [25]. To further improve the utilization of noble metal and reduce the cost of catalysts, the single atom catalysts (SACs) have received extensive attention since 2011 [26]. Single atom as active center can maximum the number of surface active sites, increase the contact chance of VOCs with active sites, and promote the diffusion of low concentration VOCs, thereby could significantly enhance the elimination efficiency of VOCs [27–30]. For instance, the highly dispersed Pt atom and strong interaction between support and Pt improve the redox properties, causing the low temperature elimination of HCHO [27]. Due to the high distortion degree, Pt1-CeO2{100} exhibits excellent catalytic efficiency for methanol removal [28]. In our previous study [30], 0.25 Pt1/meso-Fe2O3 exhibits good catalytic activity and thermal stability for the abatement of benzene, due to the strong interaction between mesoporous Fe2O3 and Pt. However, these SACs are mainly used for the thermal catalytic elimination of VOCs, their application in light-driven photothermal catalytic oxidation of VOCs has not been reported so far.

Fe(NO3)3‧9H2O (≥ 98.5 wt%) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. and Ltd, and Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2 (Pt ≥ 50.0 wt%) was received from Sigma-Aldrich Co.. All the chemical materials were used directly without any purification.

The Fe2O3 supports were prepared by the thermal decomposition method. Firstly, 40 g of Fe(NO3)3‧9H2O were added into a quartz crucible (200 mL) and calcined in a muffle oven at 550 °C (ramp rate 5 °C/min) for 120 min. The obtained dark red powders were well ground in agate mortar for 10 min and sealed in a glass bottle.

The x Pt1/Fe2O3 (x = 0.25 and 0.5 wt%, the theoretical Pt loading) catalysts were fabricated via a novel and simple impregnation-pyrolysis method. In a typical synthesis, 2 g of Fe2O3 were pretreated in vacuum oven at 200 °C for 12 h to remove the surface adsorbed species (e.g. oxygen and water). Then stoichiometric amount of Pt solution was quickly dropped on the surface of Fe2O3 powders. The wet red powders were placed in a muffle furnace and calcined at 120 °C and 550 °C (ramp rate 5 °C/min) for 60 and 120 min, respectively, to obtain the x Pt1/Fe2O3 (x = 0.25 and 0.5 wt%) catalysts. The real Pt loading contents of all samples were analyzed by using of inductively coupled plasma spectrometry-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES), as summarized in Table S1.

The physicochemical properties of the samples were investigated by means of X-ray diffraction (XRD), the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) technique, 57Fe Mössbauer spectra, aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM), UV–vis-IR diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS), hydrogen-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), thermal desorption-online GC/MS analysis (TD-GC/MS), and in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFTS).

The solar light-driven photothermal catalytic oxidation of toluene was evaluated in a self-designed stainless-steel reactor with a small round quartz window (inner diameter = 40 mm). A 300 W Xenon lamp source (PLS-SXE300D/300DUV, Beijing Perfectlight) equipped with a UV–vis-IR filter (λ = 320 − 2500 nm)/UV–vis filter (λ = 320 − 780 nm) was used to simulate solar irradiation. The Vis-IR, Vis, and IR light were obtained by placing the cutoff filter (420 or 800 nm) in the front of the Xenon lamp. The real irradiation light intensity of Xenon lamp was measured by using an optical power meter (PM100D + S425C, Thorlabs).

Before the catalytic evaluation test, 100 mg of catalyst was ultrasound dispersed in 20 mL absolute ethanol, then the suspension was uniformly coated on the surface of fiberglass membrane (diameter = 40 mm) and dried at 100 °C for 20 min. The surface temperature of catalyst was detected by the thermocouple, which was put in the center of catalyst layer. The typical reaction mixture gas was 200 ppm toluene + 20 % O2 + N2 (balance gas), and the total flow rate was 33.3 mL/min (corresponding to the weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) = 20,000 mL/(g h)). Furthermore, the photothermal catalytic stability and the effect of H2O (5 vol% and 10 vol%), CO2 (5 vol% and 10 vol%), or 20 ppm SO2 on the photothermal catalytic oxidation of toluene over the 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 catalyst were also investigated.
The detailed catalyst characterizations and photothermal catalytic evaluation procedures are described in the Supporting Information (SI).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Crystal phase composition, morphology, and textural property
ce:section.ce:para: The XRD patterns of the Fe2O3 and x Pt1/Fe2O3 (x = 0.25 and 0.5 wt%) catalysts are displayed in Fig. S1A. The typical diffraction peaks located at 2θ = 24.1 °, 33.1 °, 35.6 °, 40.9 °, 49.5 °, 54.1 °, 57.5 °, 62.4 °, 64.0 °, 72 °, and 75.4 ° are assigned to the (012), (104), (110), (113), (024), (116), (018), (214), (300), (1010), and (220) facet of rhombohedral α-Fe2O3 (JCPDS NO. 33-0664), respectively. The diffraction peaks corresponding to Pt species are not detected in x Pt1/Fe2O3 (x = 0.25 and 0.5 wt%), due to the high dispersion of Pt species and/or the low loading on the Fe2O3 supports. As shown in Fig. S2A, all samples possess similar type II isotherm with a type H3 hysteresis loop [31]. The average pore diameter of Fe2O3 and x Pt1/Fe2O3 are in the range of 38.5 − 40.7 nm (Fig. S2B and Table S1). The Fe2O3 (9.9 m2/g), 0.25 Pt1/Fe2O3 (9.6 m2/g), and 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 (9.8 m2/g) have similar specific surface areas.

The nature of Fe species in the Fe2O3 and x Pt1/Fe2O3 samples are investigated by room temperature Mössbauer spectroscopy, as displayed in Fig. S1B. The fitted hyperfine key parameters, i.e. isomer shifts (IS, mm/s), quadruple splittings (QS, mm/s), resonance half-height line widths (LW, mm/s), and magnetic hyperfine field (Bhf, Tesla), are summarized in Table S2. The spectra of all samples are well fitted with one sextet of magnetic splitting. Interestingly, it could be observed that the relative absorption intensity of 0.25 Pt1/Fe2O3 and 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 decreases and increases as compared to the Fe2O3 support, respectively, which is in good agreement with the XRD results. From the IS, QS, and Bhf parameters, it is found that the chemical environment of Fe element is not changed after the loading of single atom Pt. The IS values of Fe2O3 (0.37 mm/s), 0.25 Pt1/Fe2O3 (0.37 mm/s), and 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 (0.37 mm/s) are lower than 0.5 mm/s, which demonstrates that iron is +3 valence state in all samples [32]. However, the line width of 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 (0.28 mm/s) slightly rises as compared with that of the Fe2O3 (0.27 mm/s) support, due to the magnetic field distribution from the local lattice distortion [33]. Generally, it means that there are more lattice defects on 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3. The increase in the defect sites could improve the catalytic performance, as reported in our previous study [34].

HAADF-STEM technique is firstly used to investigate the existence state of Pt and surface morphology of 0.25 Pt1/Fe2O3 and 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3. As shown in Fig. S3A and Fig. 1 A are the HAADF-STEM images of 0.25 Pt1/Fe2O3 and 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3, respectively. It can be seen clearly that Pt is atomically dispersed on the surface of Fe2O3, and no Pt clusters or nanoparticles are observed (Fig. S4 and Fig. S5). The EDS elemental mapping images (Fig. 1B) reveal that Pt, O, and Fe elements are uniformly distributed over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3. CO in-situ DRIFTS is another powerful technique to prove the existence of single atom Pt. As shown in Fig. 1C and Fig. S6, the bands located at 2171 and 2112 cm−1 are ascribed to gaseous CO [35–37]. There is only one band at 2104 cm−1 left after purging the sample with N2, which could be ascribed to CO linear adsorption on the sites of positively charged Pt [36]. Furthermore, we have tried to investigate the electronic states and structures of the single atom Pt catalysts via XAFS analysis. Unfortunately, the signal could be interfered with the fluorescence. Meanwhile, XAS analysis of supported Pt species can be difficult to interpret, when there is coexistence of multiple single site species or the co‐existence of small clusters and Pt species [37]. The two analytical results (HAADF-STEM and CO in-situ DRIFTS) can prove that we have successfully prepared the single atom Pt catalysts.

According to the literature, the optical absorption property of the material is one of the critical factors that influence the photothermal catalytic activity. Therefore, the UV–vis-IR DRS measurement is carried out to investigate the light absorption capacity of all samples. The UV–vis-IR spectra of all samples are shown in Fig. S7. The optical property of Fe2O3 is not changed after the low loading of Pt. All samples have a similar strong absorption in the whole solar spectrum range (200 − 2500 nm), which means that these catalysts have high utilization efficiency of sunlight.

The photothermal catalytic activities of all samples for toluene oxidation are evaluated under the irradiation of simulated sunlight with light intensity of 720 mW/cm2), as shown in Fig. 2 A. Fe2O3 support shows very poor catalytic activity for toluene oxidation, and the conversion is only 0.8 %. The loading of single atom Pt can significantly improve the catalytic activity. The 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 catalyst exhibits the highest catalytic activity for toluene oxidation. The toluene conversion and CO2 yield (95 %, 87 %) over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 are higher than that (89 %, 80 %) over 0.25 Pt1/Fe2O3 and Fe2O3 (0.8 %, 0.7 %). After comparing the toluene and CO2 yield curves, one can deduce that some intermediates are formed in the process of toluene oxidation. This speculation is confirmed by the following results of TD-GC/MS (Fig. 5A). In order to eliminate the influence of other factors during the reaction, a blank experiment without catalyst coated on the surface of fiberglass membrane is conducted under the same reaction conditions. The toluene conversion and CO2 yield could be negligible, suggesting that toluene could not be oxidized into CO2 and H2O without catalyst. To better compare the catalytic activity of all samples, the turnover frequency of Pt (TOFPt) and specific reaction rate are calculated based on the molar amount and weight of Pt at 150 °C, as summarized in Table S3. The TOFPt and specific reaction rate over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 (0.213 (×10−3 s−1), 1.090 (×10−6 mol/(gPt s))) are higher than that over 0.25 Pt1/Fe2O3 (0.164 (×10−3 s−1), 0.843 (×10−6 mol/(gPt s))). Compared with the supported Pt catalysts reported in the literature (Table S4), the TOFPt value over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 is higher than that over 1.0 wt% Pt/MOR (0.035 (×10−3 s−1)) [38], 1.0 wt% Pt/Al2O3-CeO2 (0.204 (×10−3 s−1)) [39], 0.93 wt% Pt/KIT-6 (0.106 (×10−3 s−1)) [40], and lower than that over 0.12 wt% Pt/TiO2 (5.915 (×10−3 s−1)) [9] and 0.24 wt% Pt/CeO2 (6.750 (×10−3 s−1)) [41].

The influence of light intensity on photothermal catalytic activity of 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 for toluene oxidation is further investigated, and the results are shown in Fig. 2B. Generally, the toluene conversion and CO2 yield are closely related to the light intensity, and the increase in light intensity improves the catalytic activity. When the light intensity increases from 250 to 720 mW/cm2, the toluene conversion and CO2 yield increase from 1% to 95 %, and 0.8%–87%, respectively. In addition, the surface center temperatures of catalyst layer are measured under the irradiation with different light intensities (Table S5). It is shown that the temperature of catalyst layer increases from 110 to 210 °C. Therefore, it can be concluded that light intensity plays a crucial role in the catalytic reaction.

To verify whether conventional photocatalysis occurs during the reaction, we investigate the catalytic activity of 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 under the irradiation of simulated sunlight (720 mW/cm2) at low temperature. As shown in Fig. S8, the toluene conversion and CO2 yield are close to 0%, indicating there is no conventional photocatalytic reaction during toluene oxidation. To put it another way, the good activity of 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 stems from the sunlight-driven thermal catalysis. The catalyst can quickly convert the absorbed sunlight into heat, which increases the surface temperature of catalyst, and results in the degradation of toluene. In order to measure the photothermal conversion ability of all samples, the surface temperature of the catalyst is recorded (Fig. S9). The surface center temperatures of Fe2O3, 0.25 Pt1/Fe2O3 and 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 can rapidly rise to about 210 °C and remain constant under the irradiation of simulated sunlight (720 mW/cm2). However, the maximum temperature of blank membrane is only 112 °C. These results indicate that all samples exhibit excellent light-thermal conversion ability.

In order to better understand which region of sunlight spectrum contributing the photothermal catalytic oxidation of toluene, we compare the catalytic activities of 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 under the irradiation of UV–vis-IR, UV–vis and IR light, respectively (Fig. 3 A and Fig. S10). Fig. 3A shows that when the light intensity is 720 mW/cm2, the toluene conversion and CO2 yield under the irradiation of UV–vis (97 %, 90 %) are higher than that of UV–vis-IR (95 %, 87 %) and IR (92 %, 83 %), and the corresponding temperature is 224, 210, and 199 °C, respectively. Meanwhile, in order to probe the effect of photo energy on catalytic activity, the surface temperature is kept at 210 °C by adjusting the light intensity of UV–vis-IR (720 mW/cm2), UV–vis (650 mW/cm2) and IR (760 mW/cm2) light. Interestingly, the toluene conversion and CO2 yield over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 remain constant. These results show that the UV–vis light greatly enhances the photothermal conversion (increasing the surface temperature of catalyst), and the catalytic activity of 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 completely depends on the temperature.

In addition, to deeply investigate the role of different light in the whole solar spectrum for toluene oxidation over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3, the UV–vis-IR light (720 mW/cm2) is subdivided into IR (340 mW/cm2), Vis-IR (600 mW/cm2), Vis (250 mW/cm2) and UV–vis (350 mW/cm2) by placing cut-off filter and replacing filter in the front of lamp, as shown in Fig. 3B. Obviously, 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 shows the best performance under the illumination of Vis-IR light. The toluene conversion and CO2 yield under the illumination of Vis-IR (87 %, 78 %) light are much higher than that of UV–vis (3.5 %, 2.6 %), IR (1.8 %, 1.1 %), Vis (1.2 %, 0.9 %) light, respectively. It implies that Vis-IR light plays an important role in the photothermal catalytic oxidation of toluene over the 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 catalyst. Totally speaking, toluene oxidation over 0.5Pt1/Fe2O3 is the light-driven thermal catalysis process.

Based on the above results, we conclude that toluene oxidation over SACs is the light-driven thermal catalysis process, and the key factor to the catalytic activity is heat for toluene oxidation over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3. Furthermore, it also implies that Vis-IR light plays an important role in the photothermal catalytic oxidation of toluene over the 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 catalyst in the whole solar spectrum.

Previously, we found that the excellent thermal catalytic activity of catalysts was associated with the reducibility and surface element composition of catalysts [10,42]. Therefore, H2-TPR technique is first employed to probe the reducibility of all samples, and the profiles are displayed in Fig. 4
A. In general, two main reduction peaks are observed centered at about 352 °C (Ⅰ) and 567 − 740 °C (Ⅱ) for the Fe2O3 support. The peak Ⅰ and Ⅱ can be assigned to the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, and Fe3O4 to FeO, to Fe [34], respectively. For the 0.25 Pt1/Fe2O3 and 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 samples, a very weak peak around 76 − 80 °C appears after the loading of single atom Pt, which can be ascribed to the reduction of PtO x (Pt4+ and Pt2+) to Pt [43]. Furthermore, the reduction temperature of peak Ⅰ and Ⅱ shift to lower temperature, demonstrating that there is a strong interaction between single atom Pt and Fe2O3. The strong interaction improves the low temperature reducibility of the catalyst, which benefits the catalytic activity. The 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 catalyst exhibits the lowest reduction temperature (i.e. the best low temperature reducibility), and its best photothermal catalytic activity for toluene oxidation is understandable.

The chemical states and surface chemical composition of all samples are investigated by XPS technique. The Fe 2p and Pt 4f XPS spectra are shown Fig. S11 and the relevant discussion are described in SI. The O1 s XPS spectra are shown in Fig. 4B. The asymmetrical O 1s spectrum of each sample can be fitted into three peaks. The binding energies at 530.0, 531.4, and 532.5 eV can be attributed to the surface lattice oxygen (OL) species, surface adsorbed oxygen (OA, i.e., O2 −, O−, or O2 2−) species, and surface adsorbed water species, respectively [44]. According to the literature [44,45], the OA species play a crucial role for the oxidation of toluene. The higher OA concentration, the better activity of catalyst. The OA/OL molar ratio of all sample are listed in the Table S1. OA/OL molar ratio of 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 (0.27) is slightly higher than that of 0.25 Pt1/Fe2O3 (0.25), and Fe2O3 (0.23). In other words, OA may be not the key factor for the catalytic activity in the present study.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Photothermal catalytic mechanism for toluene oxidation over Pt1/Fe2O3
ce:section.ce:para: TD-GC/MS technique is employed to analyze the possible products at different conversion of toluene over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3, and the results are shown in Fig. 5 A and Table S6. Furthermore, the detailed toxicological information of the reaction intermediate products is summarized in Table S7. Several kinds of intermediates, including ethanol, acetic acid, ethyl acetate, benzene, m-xylene, p-xylene, o-xylene, and benzaldehyde are detected during the oxidation of toluene. Among the intermediates, benzene might be the key intermediate, which is assigned to the disproportionate reaction of toluene or the oxidation of benzyl alcohol [46]. The benzene yield increases slowly at first and then decreases with the increase of reaction temperature. The intermediates with low molecular weight (i.e. ethanol, acetic acid, and ethyl acetate) are only observed above T50 %, due to the cracking of benzene ring and deep oxidation of toluene.

In-situ DRIFTS experiment is carried out to further understand the reaction mechanism of toluene oxidation. Fig. 5B gives the in-situ DRIFTS spectra of toluene oxidation over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 at different temperature. The negative absorption bands located at 3740 and 3716 cm−1 are ascribed to the stretching vibration of hydroxyl ν(Fe − OH) and adsorbed molecular water coordinated to the surface Fe ions [46]. The bands at 3070 and 2934 cm−1 can be ascribed to CH stretching vibration of the aromatic ring and symmetric stretching vibration of methylene (−CH2) group, respectively [47,48]. The bands located at 1600, 1508, and 1495 cm−1 belong to the in-plane skeleton vibration of the aromatic ring [48,49]. However, the intensity of toluene characteristic peaks is very weak, suggesting the weak adsorption of toluene or adsorbed toluene could be partially oxidized over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 at 100 °C. The band at 1620 cm−1 could be assigned to the skeleton stretching vibration of aromatic ring in benzene (the key intermediate detected by the TDGC/MS technique) [46]. Furthermore, some new characteristic bands of intermediates (i.e. benzyl alcohol, benzaldehyde, benzoate, maleic anhydride, and ethanol species) are detected when the temperature is at 120 °C, indicating that toluene can be oxidized at low temperature. The bands at 1689 and 1662 cm−1 are regarded as the CO symmetric stretching vibration of aldehydic species, which directly demonstrates the formation of benzaldehyde [9,47]. The strong band around 1402 cm−1 can be attributed to the C − O symmetric stretching vibration of benzoate species [46]. Besides, the other two bands at 1520 and 1360 cm−1 belonging to benzoate are also observed [46,48]. The band at 1155 cm−1 assigned to alkoxide species indicates the formation of ethanol or benzyl alcohol [46]. Obviously, the intensity of the bands due to the benzyl alcohol, benzaldehyde, and benzoate species increases with a rise in the reaction temperature from 120 to 240 °C, which means that toluene oxidation follows the benzoate salt reaction route [49]. The bands at 1854 and 1788 cm−1 are attributed to the CO stretching vibrations of maleic anhydride (OC − O − CO) [50]. The appearance of ethanol and maleic anhydride means the opening of the aromatic ring. Moreover, the characteristic bands (2360 and 2340 cm−1) of adsorbed CO2 are also detected [12], and their intensities increase with a rise in the reaction temperature.

According to the results of TD-GC/MS and in-situ DRIFTS experiments, a possible photothermal catalytic mechanism for toluene oxidation over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 is proposed (Scheme 1 ). The toluene molecules are adsorbed on the active sites of the 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 catalyst. Before the opening of benzene ring, two possible routes could simultaneously proceed. The adsorbed toluene molecules could be successively oxidized into benzyl alcohol, benzaldehyde, and benzoic acid, or give rise to benzene and p-xylene via the disproportionation reaction. o-xylene and m-xylene might be generated from the p-xylene isomerization reaction. With a rise in the surface temperature, these aromatic compounds are further oxidized into a series of small molecules, e.g. maleic anhydride, ethanol, acetone, and ethyl acetate. Finally, the intermediate species are completely mineralized to H2O and CO2.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Photothermal catalytic stability and H2O, CO2, and SO2 tolerance
ce:section.ce:para: The catalytic stability is an important parameter for the performance evaluation of a catalyst (especially for the single atom catalyst). Hence, we carry out the on-stream test for the oxidation of toluene over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 under the irradiation of simulated sunlight (720 mW/cm2, 210 °C). As shown in Fig. 6 A, toluene conversion could be stabilized at around 95 % within 36-h continuous test, indicating that 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 possesses good catalytic stability.

Usually, the industrial exhaust emissions are composed of various compositions, such as H2O, CO2, and SO2. Therefore, the effects of H2O, CO2, and SO2 on the photothermal catalytic activity of 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 are further investigated. After introducing 5 vol%, and 10 vol% H2O into the reaction system, toluene conversion slightly decreases (Fig. 6B), due to the competitive adsorption of H2O, toluene, and O2 on the active sites of catalyst [44,45]. Toluene conversion could be recovered after cutting off H2O, suggesting that the deactivation caused by the presence of H2O is reversible. The addition of CO2 has negligible effect on toluene conversion (Fig. 6C) over 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3. It may be due to the adsorption of CO2 is weaker than that of O2 and toluene over single atom active sites [30]. Unlike the presence of H2O or CO2, toluene conversion gradually decreases from 95 % to 90 % after the introduction of 20 ppm SO2 (Fig. 6D). This negative effect might be attributed to the cumulative adsorption of SO2 or the formation of sulfite species on the surface of catalyst. After cutting off SO2, toluene conversion gradually returns to 94 %, due to the desorption of SO2 or decomposition of sulﬁte species from the active sites [12]. The crystal phase structure of the used 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 catalyst is shown in Fig. S12. It is observed that the crystal phase structure could be well maintained after being treated under different conditions. In other words, the present 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 sample exhibits high photothermal catalytic stability. Fig. S13 gives the HAADF-STEM images of the used 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 sample. Only a small portion of single atom Pt is aggregated into clusters within 36 h on-stream reaction, further demonstrating the excellent stability of the 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 catalysts.

In this work, a novel and simple impregnation-pyrolysis method is developed for the preparation of the Fe2O3 supported single atom Pt catalysts. The loading of single atom Pt can significantly improve the photothermal catalytic activity. Due to its good light-thermal conversion efficiency and low temperature reducibility, the 0.5 Pt1/Fe2O3 catalyst exhibits the best photothermal catalytic activity (the toluene conversion and CO2 yield are 95 % and 87 %, respectively) under the irradiation of simulated sunlight with light intensity of 720 mW/cm2. The possible reaction pathways for the photothermal catalytic oxidation of toluene are proposed over single atom Pt catalysts. Generally, the present study develops the photothermal catalytic purification technique for VOCs removal over the supported single atom noble metal catalysts.
Zhiwei Wang: Carried out experiments, wrote and modified the manuscript.
Shaohua Xie and Ying Feng: Catalyst preparation.
Peijie Ma and Kun Zheng: HAADF-STEM characterization.
Erhong Duan, Yuxi Liu, and Hongxing Dai: Analyzed the experimental results.
Jiguang Deng: Designed the experiments, analyzed the experimental results, wrote and modified the manuscript.
